<mol-help-info i18n-tooltip="@@metadata-sections:range-map-landing:select-taxonomic-group:tooltip" tooltip="The taxonomic group of the dataset"></mol-help-info>

<mol-help-info i18n-tooltip="@@metadata-sections:title:description:tooltip" tooltip="Provide description (or abstract) for the dataset. This can include a brief summary of the reason for the study, hypotheses, methods, results, and/or a conclusion, and should provide enough information to help potential users of the data understand if it may be of interest to them."></mol-help-info>

<mol-help-info i18n-tooltip="@@metadata-sections:title:geographic-coverage:tooltip" tooltip="Provide a description of the geographic coverage; for example, 'The study surveyed the high elevations of Santa Cruz, Isabela, and Fernandina Islands in the Galapagos, Ecuador.'"></mol-help-info>
<mol-help-info i18n-tooltip="@@metadata-sections:temporal-coverage:number-of-days:tooltip" tooltip="The total number of days spent surveying."></mol-help-info>
<mol-help-info i18n-tooltip="@@metadata-sections:temporal-coverage:study-diurnality:tooltip" tooltip="Time of day sampling was conducted (day, night, both)."></mol-help-info>

<mol-help-info i18n-tooltip="@@metadata-sections:temporal-coverage:season:tooltip" tooltip="Season(s) in which the study was conducted (e.g., spring, summer, winter, fall, wet, dry, breeding)."></mol-help-info>

<mol-help-info i18n-tooltip="@@metadata-sections:taxonomic-coverage:class:tooltip" tooltip="Scientific name of the taxonomic class surveyed (e.g., Amphibia, Reptilia, Mammalia, Insecta, Aves)."></mol-help-info>

<mol-help-info i18n-tooltip="@@metadata-sections:taxonomic-coverage:taxonomic-scope:tooltip" tooltip="Indicate if the entire class or only a subset of that class was studied. If the whole class is included, indicate mammals, reptiles, insects, etc. If only part of a class was inventoried, indicate this (e.g., small mammals, water birds, Rodentia, Nymphalidae). Scientific name or common name accepted."></mol-help-info>

<mol-help-info i18n-tooltip="@@metadata-sections:survey-protocol:survey-methods:tooltip" tooltip="Provide specific details about the survey methods, such as protocols followed, equipment used, number of transects or plots, etc."></mol-help-info>
<mol-help-info i18n-tooltip="@@metadata-sections:survey-dates:start-date:tooltip" tooltip="The date that data collection began for this dataset."> </mol-help-info>
<mol-help-info i18n-tooltip="@@metadata-sections:survey-dates:end-date:tooltip" tooltip="The date that data collection ended for this dataset."></mol-help-info>

<mol-help-info i18n-tooltip="@@metadata-sections:sampling:sampling-descriptions:tooltip" tooltip="Describe the sampling procedures used in the research project. This should be similar to a description of sampling procedures found in the methods section of a journal article."></mol-help-info>

<mol-help-info i18n-tooltip="@@metadata-sections:release-policy:no-release-date:tooltip" tooltip="You do not need to set the release date, but if this is selected, an email reminder will be sent every 6 months to set a release date."></mol-help-info>
<mol-help-info i18n-tooltip="@@metadata-sections:quality-control:quality-control-tooltip" tooltip="Describe the actions taken to control and assess the quality of data."></mol-help-info>
Make available for MOL internal use in models
<mol-help-info i18n-tooltip="@@metdata-sections:permissions:mol-models-tooltip" tooltip="Allow the Map of Life team to use this dataset for modeling."></mol-help-info>
<mol-help-info i18n-tooltip tooltip="Allow the public to see this dataset."></mol-help-info>
<mol-help-info i18n-tooltip tooltip="Data are made available to GBIF and other data partners and available for download, together with citation and license information."></mol-help-info>

<mol-help-info i18n-tooltip="@@metadata-sections:methods:inventories-compilations-both-tooltip" tooltip="Select the method used to compile the inventory. Selecting 'inventory' indicates that the species data consist of observations made by the surveyors, 'compilation' means that the authors compiled a species list using other sources (e.g., historical evidence, other publications), while 'both' means that both methods were used."></mol-help-info>

<mol-help-info i18n-tooltip="@@metadata-sections:methods:survey-methods:tooltip" tooltip="Provide specific details about the survey methods, such as protocols followed, equipment used, number of transects or plots, etc."></mol-help-info>
<mol-help-info i18n-tooltip="@@metadata-sections:license:license-tooltip" tooltip="Choose the appropriate license for the dataset."> </mol-help-info>
<mol-help-info i18n-tooltip="@@metadata-sections:license:license-holder-hint" tooltip="The person or organization who holds the license. "> </mol-help-info>
<mol-help-info i18n-tooltip="@@metadata-sections:geographic-coverage:geometry-processing:tooltip" tooltip="What methods were used to process the geometries."></mol-help-info>
<mol-help-info i18n-tooltip="@@metadata-sections:geographic-coverage:countries:tooltip" tooltip="List of countries covered by this dataset. Strongly recommended."></mol-help-info>
<mol-help-info i18n-tooltip="@@metadata-sections:geographic-coverage:geographic-scope:tooltip" tooltip="Generalized extent, may be continent, state, region, national park, etc."></mol-help-info>

<mol-help-info i18n-tooltip="@@metadata-sections:geographic-coverage-inventory:spatial-extent-tooltip" tooltip="Record the name of the study area (e.g., county, national park, reserve, island, mountain range) or a brief description of where the study was located. Examples include: Yosemite National Park, the Galapagos, Sierra Madre Mountains, sites with exposed limestone/sandstone substrates in western Madagascar, and a 5 km2 portion of deforested land in Los Tres Picachos Forest."></mol-help-info>

<mol-help-info i18n-tooltip="@@metadata-sections:geographic-coverage-inventory:site-details-tooltip" tooltip="Record any habitat, climate, disturbance, or other details that describe the study site."></mol-help-info>
<mat-hint i18n="@@metadata-sections:geographic-coverage-inventory:site-details-hint">Author reported site information (utilizes terms below per site if more than one)</mat-hint>
<mol-help-info i18n-tooltip="@@metadata-sections:general:project-url-tooltip" tooltip="URL of the source, paper, or institution."></mol-help-info>
<mol-help-info i18n-tooltip="@@metadata-sections:general:notes-tooltip" tooltip="Provide any additional notes that you would like to include about this dataset."></mol-help-info>
<mol-help-info i18n-tooltip="@@metadata-sections:general:keywords-tooltip" tooltip="List keywords associated with this study."></mol-help-info>

<mol-help-info i18n-tooltip="@@metadata-sections:completeness:completeness-tooltip" tooltip="Assess the representativeness of the species list for the study area and taxonomic scope. For example, were all of the amphibians in the study area recorded, or does the inventory only reflect half of the amphibians present? Completeness can be inferred from survey effort and methods and can be assessed using the length and timing of the study, spatial extent of sampling, inclusion of all habitats present in study area, expertise of individuals conducting the inventory, and/or species accumulation curves."></mol-help-info>

<mol-help-info i18n-tooltip="@@metadata-sections:completeness:lower-bound-tooltip" tooltip="Inferred completeness is captured in quartiles (i.e., 0, 25, 50, 75). Indicate the lower bound of completeness percentage for the study. For example, if you believe the inventory represents 25-50% of the species present in the area, indicate a value of 25 for the lower bound."></mol-help-info>

<mol-help-info i18n-tooltip="@@metadata-sections:completeness:upper-bound-tooltip" tooltip="Inferred completeness is captured in quartiles (i.e., 25, 50, 75, 100). Indicate the upper bound of completeness percentage for the study. For example, if you believe the inventory represents 25-50% of the species present in the area, indicate a value of 50 for the upper bound."></mol-help-info>

<mol-help-info i18n-tooltip="@@metadata-sections:completeness:rationale-tooltip" tooltip="Provide an explanation for your completeness score. Examples of high completeness: the surveyors used several different survey methods to inventory the target taxonomic group (i.e., Ungulates); the surveyors made great effort to survey each habitat type in the study area that a species from the target group would be found in; the authors utilized several resources such as museum specimens and primary literature to produce a complete inventory. Examples of low completeness: the study length was not appropriate for the size of the area; inappropriate or insufficient methods were used for the target group; the study area was difficult to traverse/hard to access."></mol-help-info>
<mol-help-info i18n-tooltip="@@metadata-sections:citation-section:doi-tooltip" tooltip="Digital Object Identifier (DOI) for the dataset or source."></mol-help-info>
<mol-help-info i18n-tooltip="@@metadata-sections:citation-section:isbn-tooltip" tooltip="International Standard Book Number (ISBN) for a book."></mol-help-info>
<mol-help-info i18n-tooltip="@@metadata-sections:citation-tooltip" tooltip="Full citation of the source of the dataset, in APA style."></mol-help-info>
<mol-help-info i18n-tooltip="@@metadata-sections:endemic-tooltip" tooltip="Information about how this species is endemic to the region."></mol-help-info>
We didn't find a recorded_by field in your records. Please specify the name of the person that recorded the observations:
<mat-hint i18n="@@match-columns-recorded-by-info">Value will be applied to all rows in the dataset</mat-hint>
<mat-hint i18n="@@files-form:basic-info:form:taxonomic-group-hint">Select from the list of groups currently supported by MOL</mat-hint>
Select how the spatial data are stored: Shapefile (polygon) or CSV (coordinates)
Select the shape of the study area in reference to the provided coordinates.
<button mat-button class="mol-button basic primary" (click)="openCoordinateTypeModal()" i18n="@@files-form:basic-info:form:study-area-title">Define Study Area</button>
<button mat-button (click)="nextStep()" [disabled]="!stepComplete(1)" class="mol-button primary basic next" i18n="@@next"> Next </button>
The species names and spatial data are in:
Single CSV file - One file with species names and coordinates
Separate CSV files - One file with species and region name(s), and a second file with coordinates and region name(s)

<mat-hint *ngIf="datasetType === 'Inventory' && selectedGeometryFormat === 'shapefile'" i18n="@@files-form:upload-files:inventory:shapefile:requirements"> Required: a zipped folder with .shp, .dbf, .prj, and .shx files </mat-hint>
Please fix the following issues and upload the file again.
<button mat-button (click)="previousStep()" class="mol-button primary stroked next" i18n="@@back"> Back </button>
<button mat-button (click)="nextStep()" [disabled]="!stepComplete(2)" class="mol-button primary basic next" i18n="@@next"> Next </button>

Data preparation steps vary depending on the dataset type. The following guidelines provide detailed information on how the data should be formatted for each type of dataset. We strongly recommend that you label the columns in your data tables according to the example provided. You will have a chance to check that the column names in the dataset are being matched to Map of Life fields, but the upload process will be easier if you format the files accordingly before upload. Additional fields can be included, preferably with the field names in lower camel case. Additional column names must not contain whitespace.
If you have additional information you'd like to include, simply add extra columns in the .CSV file to the right of the species names.
Please fix the following issues and upload the file again.
<button mat-button (click)="previousStep()" class="mol-button primary stroked next" i18n="@@back"> Back </button>
<button mat-button (click)="nextStep()" [disabled]="!stepComplete(3)" class="mol-button primary basic next" i18n="@@next"> Next </button>
Please be assured that if you upload data that does not match our existing metadata terms, they will still be uploaded to the database and stored with the rest of your data.
<button mat-button (click)="previousStep()" class="mol-button primary stroked next" i18n="@@back"> Back </button>
<button mat-button (click)="nextStep()" [disabled]="!stepComplete(4)" class="mol-button primary basic next" i18n="@@next"> Next </button>

Explore the map preview to verify that the spatial information you provided in the uploaded files is correct. If the study areas are not plotting correctly, please go back to the upload files step and upload corrected spatial data. If you continue to have problems, please contact us at info@mol.org.
<button mat-button (click)="previousStep()" class="mol-button primary stroked next" i18n="@@back"> Back </button>
<button mat-button type="button" (click)="nextPage()" [disabled]="!stepComplete(5)" class="mol-button primary basic next" i18n="@@submit"> Submit </button>
Any attributes you apply to this range map will apply to all of the shapes in the map. If you need separate attributes, you can create another range map immediately after submitting.

<mol-help-info  i18n-tooltip="@@metadata-sections:feature-attributes-dialog:presence:tooltip" tooltip="Extant - The species is known or thought to likely occur presently in the area. Possibly Extant - There is no record of the species in the area, but the species may possibly occur, based on the distribution of potentially suitable habitat at appropriate altitudes. Extinct – The species was formerly known or thought very likely to occur in the area, but it has been confirmed that the species no longer occurs here."></mol-help-info>

<mol-help-info i18n-tooltip="@@metadata-sections:feature-attributes-dialog:origin:tooltip" tooltip="Why or how is the species in this area? (Native - The species is/was native to the area.  Non-native - The species has not historically been found here, but currently inhabits the area.)"></mol-help-info>

<mol-help-info i18n-tooltip="@@metadata-sections:feature-attributes-dialog:seasonality:tooltip" tooltip="What is the seasonal presence of the species in the area?   Resident - the species is/was known or thought very likely to be present throughout the year.  Breeding Season – The species is/was known or thought very likely to occur regularly during the breeding season and to breed.  Non-breeding Season – The species is/was known or thought very likely to occur regularly during the non-breeding season of the species.Passage – The species is/was known or thought very likely to occur regularly during a relatively short period of the year on migration between breeding and non-breeding ranges."></mol-help-info>

<mol-help-info i18n-tooltip="@@feature-attributes-dialog:temporal-scope:tooltip" tooltip="Identify the starting and ending years of the study. This would be the very start and the very end years the study was carried out."></mol-help-info>
<mat-option value='species' selected i18n="@@number-of-species"> Number of Species </mat-option>
Are you sure you want to delete this dataset?
Position of coordinate in study area
<mat-hint i18n="@@coordinate-type-modal:size-hint"> If you don't know the size of your study area, consider uploading your data as an occurrence dataset instead. </mat-hint>
Position of coordinate in study area
<mat-hint i18n="@@coordinate-type-modal:size-hint"> If you don't know the size of your study area, consider uploading your data as an occurrence dataset instead. </mat-hint>
Position of coordinate in study area
